properties.name: King Caspar
properties.description: painting by Hendrick Heerschop, Berlijn, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Gemäldegalerie
properties.exhibit: Legend has it that one of the three magi who came to worship the Christ child was an African. Sometimes he is called Caspar, sometimes Balthasar. Heerschop painted him without surroundings or story. He can only be identified from his expensive clothes and the jar of incense he gave as his gift. But it is the man’s face that attracts the most attention; he looks at us proudly and self-confidently.

properties.name: oak
properties.description: type of wood obtained from oak trees

But it is the man’s face that attracts the most attention; he looks at us proudly and self-confidently.

properties.name: Saint Caspar
properties.description: according to Christian tradition, a king of India and one of the three Magi (younger than Melchior, older than Balthazar) that visited Jesus, who gave the gift of frankincense

properties.name: Head of a Boy in a Turban
properties.description: painting by Gerrit Dou, Hannover, Niedersächsisches Landesmuseum Hannover
properties.exhibit: Dou was Rembrandt’s first pupil. He took up his master’s idea of studying black people. The result was this endearing tronie of a young man in a fantasy costume, who looks at us over his shoulder.

properties.name: Don Miguel de Castro, Emissary of Congo
properties.description: painting by Jasper of Jeronimus Beckx, Kopenhagen, Statensmuseum for Kunst
properties.exhibit:
Dom Miguel de Castro makes here a powerful, serious expression. He was a member of the Congolese elite. This portrait was commissioned by the Dutch West India Company. The WIC and the Congolese rulers traded in gold an ivory, but mainly in people. This is why Dom Miguel now is seen as a controversial figure. 
Dom Miguel wears fashionable European clothes. This is probably the suit he had acquired in Brazil, when he had visited the Dutch colony earlier.

properties.name: panel
properties.description: painting surface made of a thin wooden plank

properties.name: Diego Bemba, a Servant of Don Miguel de Castro
properties.description: painting by Jasper of Jeronimus Beckx, Kopenhagen, Statensmuseum for Kunst
properties.exhibit: We know the names of these three men from the inscriptions on the backs of the paintings. This is Diego Bemba. He holds a small casket, probably a diplomatic gift. He was one of Don Miguel de Castro’s servants.

properties.name: Pedro Sunda, a Servant of Don Miguel de Castro
properties.description: painting by Jasper of Jeronimus Beckx, Kopenhagen, Statensmuseum for Kunst
properties.exhibit: Pedro Sunda holds an elephant’s tusk. Ivory was one of the Congo’s major export products. The status of these young men is unclear. Were they assistants of the noble Dom Miguel or were they enslaved?

properties.name: Map of Paranambucae
properties.description: painting by Joan Blaeu / Georg Marcgraf / Frans Post
properties.exhibit: A map of the Dutch colony in the northeast of Brazil. This is how the colony was depicted. Upper right there is a sugar mill where enslaved Africans worked. There is no hint of the harsh working conditions. To the left the Africans are shown dancing and making music. For the people of the Netherlands the gruesome reality of slavery was kept out of the picture.

properties.name: paper
properties.description: thin, flexible material mainly used for writing upon, printing upon, drawing or for packaging

properties.name: Portrait of a Black Girl
properties.description: etching by Wenzel Hollar, Amsterdam, Rijksmuseum
properties.exhibit: A rare portrait etchings of black people. She wears the normal seventeenth-century clothing of the middle class. Hollar made the portrait in Antwerp, as we can see from the inscription beside the girl. The prints were intended for sale. The artist showed his skill by successfully rendering a black skin in an etching. This appealed to collectors.

properties.name: Rijksmuseum
properties.description: museum in Amsterdam, Netherlands

properties.name: Portrait of a Black Girl

properties.name: Black people

properties.name: Portrait of a Man
properties.description: painting by Wallerant Vaillant, Rijksmuseum, c. 1660-1675
properties.exhibit: Vaillant made a true likeness of this man with an individual appearance . However, this print appears to have been made to sell to collectors, not commissioned by the sitter. Vaillant was an expert in mezzotint, a technique for making prints in different shades of black. It was obviously also ideal for depicting dark skin.

properties.name: Black people
properties.description: humans typically having a degree of Sub-Saharan African ancestry

properties.name: Man in a Turban
properties.description: Red and black chalk on paper by Jan Lievens.
properties.exhibit: Lievens made this drawing in Leiden when he was working closely with his friend Rembrandt. The individual appearance makes it clear that someone modelled for this, but that model was then given a turban and a feather to wear, turning him into a Mediterranean type.

properties.name: paper
properties.description: thin, flexible material mainly used for writing upon, printing upon, drawing or for packaging

properties.name: Doritos
properties.description: Acrylics and oil on canvas by IRIÉE ZAMBLÉ, 2019.
properties.exhibit: A woman sits on a couch holding a bag of tortilla chips. Black people are now represented in art in everyday situations. The artist Iriée Zamblé expresses her feelings: ‘I still don't see enough of the people who pass me every day reflected in art. That's why I feel an urge to capture them in my paintings.’

properties.name: canvas
properties.description: painting surface made of extremely heavy-duty plain-woven fabric

properties.name: The New Utopia Begins Here: Hermina Huiswoud
properties.description: oil on canvas by Iris Kensmil, 2019
properties.exhibit: In her portraits, Kensmil focuses on black people who played important roles in history. Hermina Huiswoud (1905-1998) was a political activist. She belonged to a generation of anti-colonial thinkers, leaders and organizers who were active in the fight against European and American imperialism. After the Second World War she worked in Amsterdam, and as a supporter of the Our Suriname Association (VOS) fought for the independence of the Dutch colony.
properties.uri: The New Utopia Begins Here: Hermina Huiswoud_exhibit

properties.name: canvas
properties.description: painting surface made of extremely heavy-duty plain-woven fabric

properties.name: The Unspoken Truth
properties.description: oil on canvas by Dion Rosina, 2019
properties.exhibit: Dion Rosina used a nineteenth-century photograph of an enslaved man in Brazil for this painting, The opening is an allusion to the Netherlands' colonial past in that country -- a subject that is a hiatus in our collective memory. The past is behind the opening, but at the same time impresses itself on the viewer through the man

properties.description: humans typically having a degree of Sub-Saharan African ancestry

properties.name: Ilona
properties.description: print on canvas by Hedy Tjin, 2019
properties.exhibit:
Hedy Tjin is an illustrative designer. In her work she expresses her fascination for patterns and designs, reflecting the influence of cultural and ethnic subjects. 
Her love of working with a felt-tip pen is driven by the freedom to be able to draw anywhere and at any time, often with a therapeutic effect. She records loved ones and snapshots. Sadly, her Aunt Ilona came into her life late and left too early.

properties.name: canvas
properties.description: painting surface made of extremely heavy-duty plain-woven fabric

properties.name: Head of a Boy
properties.description: black chalk on paper by Leendert van der Cooghen, c1660-1665
properties.exhibit: This finely executed study must have been observed directly. The boy looks very lifelike. Unfortunately, we know nothing about him. Leendert van der Cooghen lived and worked in Haarlem. He made this kind of study to find out how he could depict the subject best. It was study material, not intended for sale.

properties.name: paper
properties.description: thin, flexible material mainly used for writing upon, printing upon, drawing or for packaging

properties.name: Black people
properties.description: humans typically having a degree of Sub-Saharan African ancestry

properties.name: The Market in Dam Square
properties.description: painting by Jacob van der Ulft, Amsterdam, Stadsarchief
properties.exhibit: In the seventeenth century, Amsterdam was already a multicultural city. Jewish immigrants, East Europeans, Arab traders, Asian seamen and Africans had made their homes here. This view of Dam Square offers proof. It shows a group of men in eastern turbans slightly to the left of centre. And one black figure, beside a fish stall in the foreground on the right. The number of black residents was small. Some five thousand people were living in and around the Jodenbreestraat around 1650. Around eighty of them were black – about 1.5 percent of the neighbourhood’s residents.

properties.description: thin, flexible material mainly used for writing upon, printing upon, drawing or for packaging

properties.name: The Market in Dam Square
properties.description: painting by Jacob van der Ulft, Amsterdam, Stadsarchief
properties.exhibit: In the seventeenth century, Amsterdam was already a multicultural city. Jewish immigrants, East Europeans, Arab traders, Asian seamen and Africans had made their homes here. This view of Dam Square offers proof. It shows a group of men in eastern turbans slightly to the left of centre. And one black figure, beside a fish stall in the foreground on the right. The number of black residents was small. Some five thousand people were living in and around the Jodenbreestraat around 1650. properties.name: Black people
properties.description: humans typically having a degree of Sub-Saharan African ancestry

properties.name: Two moors
properties.description: painting by Rembrandt
properties.exhibit:
It seems logical that two black neighbours of Rembrandt were the models for this painting. But the painting is dated 1661, when Rembrandt was living on Rozengracht, on the other side of Amsterdam. However, there is documentary evidence that he had already made a painting of two black men while living in Jodenbreestraat. Were there other paintings of this subject? Or did Rembrandt only finish off the first painting and date it a few years later? 
It is also unusual that Rembrandt depicted the close bond between the two men. Were they friends? Or perhaps brothers? It remains speculation, but if the models were brothers, and if they came from the neighbourhood, they may have been Bastiaan and Manuel Fernando. They were sailors from the island of São Tomé in their early twenties, who lived at the end of the street near Sint Antoniespoort.

properties.name: Dutch Golden Age painting
properties.description: painting movement
